sen.j: 合気道（あいきどう）は植芝盛平が昭和前期に創始した現代武道。
sen.e: "Aikido" is a Gendai Budo (modern martial art) founded by Morihei UESHIBA in early Showa.

sen.j: 日本古来の柔術・剣術・杖術などを基に成立した、体術を主とする総合武術である。
sen.e: It is a comprehensive martial art centered around taijutsu (a method of using the body for self defense), based on ancient Japanese jujutsu (classical Japanese martial art, usually referring to fighting without a weapon), swordplay, Jojutsu (martial art using a cane staff), etc.

sen.j: 合気道の創始者・植芝盛平は1883年（明治16年）和歌山県田辺町（現・田辺市）の富裕な農家に生まれた。
sen.e: The founder of aikido, Morihei UESHIBA, was born into a wealthy farmhouse in 1883 in Tanabe-cho, Wakayama Prefecture (present Tanabe City).

sen.j: 青年時代に起倒流・柳生心眼流などの柔術を修めた後、1915年北海道開拓中に大東流合気柔術の武田惣角に入門、1922年教授代理を許された。
sen.e: After studying jujutsu from Kito-ryu school, Yagyushingan-ryu school, etc. in his youth, he became a disciple of Sokaku TAKEDA of Daito-ryu Aiki Jujutsu (Daito style self defense technique) during the development of Hokkaido in 1915, and was accepted as substitute instructor in 1922.

sen.j: 1917年宗教団体大本に入信、京都府の綾部市や亀岡市で独自の修行を続け、甥の井上鑑昭（親英体道の創始者）と共に同地で「合気武道」の指導を行った。
sen.e: In 1917, he joined the religious group, Oomoto, and continued his own training in Ayabe City and Kameoka City in Kyoto while teaching 'Aikibudo' with his nephew Noriaki INOUE (founder of Shinei Taido martial art) in the area.

sen.e: The reputation of this 150 cm martial artist who performed peculiar techniques with his small build attracted attention in Tokyo, and he moved to Tokyo with support from full admiral, Isamu TAKESHITA, and others in 1927.

sen.j: 1976年には合気会傘下の国際合気道連盟（IAF）が結成され、 IAFは1984年GAISF（GAISF）の正式会員となり、1989年以降ワールドゲームズ大会に毎回参加している。
sen.e: In 1976, the International Aikido Federation (IAF), an affiliate of Aikikai was established, and IAF became an official member of the General Association of International Sports Federations (GAISF), participating in every World Games since 1989.
sen.cmt: 原文には「GAISF（GAISF）」とありますが、１つめのGAISFはリンク先の単語のようです。ウェブで確認すると用語が「国際競技団体総連合」となっており、本来はこちらの用語を使用していると思われますので、こちらを訳出しました。

sen.j: 近年、大東流や合気道での使用法の影響で、特に素手の武術、武道において相手の力に力で対抗せず、相手の“気”（攻撃の意志、タイミング、力のベクトルなどを含む）に自らの「“気”を合わせ」相手の攻撃を無力化させるような技法群やその原理を指すようになった（剣道や古来よりの武器術では元来の意味で使われる）。
sen.e: In recent years, influenced by its use in Daito-ryu and aikido, it refers to the techniques and principles of disabling the opponent's attacks by 'matching the "qi"' of oneself to the "qi" (including the will to attack, timing, vector of force) of the opponent, instead of competing against the opponent's force with force, especially in martial arts using bare hands (it is used for its original meaning in kendo (Japanese art of fencing) and in ancient arts of weapon).

sen.j: 嘉納治五郎が植芝盛平の合気道を見たとき嘉納治五郎は思わず”私の求めていた物はこれだ！！”と叫んだとされている。

sen.j: 盛平の有力な弟子であった塩田剛三、富木謙治、望月稔らも、植芝に入門する前は柔道の有段者であった。
sen.e: Powerful disciples of Morihei such as Gozo SHIODA, Kenji TOMIKI, and Minoru MOCHIZUKI were judo yudansha (Judo black belt) before becoming Ueshiba's disciples.

sen.j: 特に、富木や望月は植芝の高弟となってからも柔道家としての活動もおこなっており、その理念には合気道・柔道双方の影響がみられる。
sen.e: In particular, Tomiki and Mochizuki continued their activities as judo practitioners even after becoming high-caliber disciples of Ueshiba, and their philosophy reflects both aikido and judo.

sen.j: 植芝盛平は剣術の研究のために、自らの道場「皇武館」で剣道の指導を行わせた。
sen.e: Morihei UESHIBA allowed kendo training in his dojo 'Kobukan' to study swordplay.

sen.j: 実際の指導は、親交のあった中山博道（神道無念流）の3人の高弟で「有信館の三羽烏」と呼ばれた中倉清（当時は盛平の婿養子）、羽賀準一、中島五郎蔵が行った。
sen.e: Actual training was conducted by Kiyoshi NAKAKURA (adopted son-in-law of Morihei at the time), Junichi HAGA, and Gorozo NAKAJIMA, the so-called called 'trio of Yushinkan,' who were the three high-caliber disciples of a close friend, Hiromichi NAKAYAMA (the Shindo-Munen school of swordsmanship).

sen.j: 健康法としての合気道
sen.e: Aikido as a physical fitness
Aikido as a means of physical fitness

sen.j: 合気会系の道場では一般的に、稽古の始まりに盛平の考案による「合気体操」と呼ばれる鍛錬法を行うのが慣例となっている。
sen.e: In Aikikai-affiliated dojo, it is customary to perform a method of discipling called 'aiki taiso' invented by Morihei at the beginning of the training.
In Aikikai-affiliated dojo, at the start of training it is customary to perform a method of discipline called 'aiki taiso,' as invented by Morihei.

sen.j: 身体各部の柔軟など稽古前の準備運動としての性格もあるが、「鳥船」「振魂」など神道の禊の行法の一部も取り入れられており、これ単独で“気の鍛錬”・“呼吸力の鍛錬”に効果があるとされる。
sen.e: Stretching various parts of the body, it does serve as warm-up exercise before training, but some misogi (purification ceremony) gyoho (method of ascetic practices) of Shinto such as 'torifune' (bird rowing misogi exercise) and 'furutama' (soul shaking) are included, and it is believed that this alone is effective for "discipling of qi" and "discipling of breath power."

sen.j: また(財)合気会の理事であった西勝造の「西式健康法」も取り入れられている。
sen.e: Additionally, 'Nishi System of Health Engineering' by Katsuzo NISHI, the director of Aikikai Foundation, is also adopted.

sen.j: 合気道を一般に普及する上で「健康体操」「レクリエーション」という宣伝も多くなされた。
sen.e: In order to promote aikido to the general public, it was often promoted as 'health exercise' and 'recreation.'
In order to promote aikido to the general public, it was often promoted as 'health exercise' and 'recreation.'

sen.j: 合気道の稽古は、技を左右同じ動きで同回数繰り返すため、左右の身体の歪みを取る効果がある。
sen.e: Training in aikido repeats techniques using the same movements for left and right, repeating them the same number of times, so it effectively resolves distortion between the left and right sides of the body.

sen.j: 受身で畳の上を転がることにより血行を促す。
sen.e: Rolling on the tatami mat for ukemi (falling techniques) improves blood circulation.
Rolling on the tatami mat for ukemi (falling techniques) improves the blood circulation.

sen.j: また受身の習得で転倒による怪我をしにくくなる。
sen.e: Additionally, learning ukemi prevents injury from falls.
Additionally, by learning ukemi one can prevent injury due to falling.

sen.j: 関節技にかかることでストレッチ効果を得られ、五十肩などの予防になる。
sen.e: Being applied joint-locking techniques has the effect of doing stretches, and prevents frozen shoulder.
The application of joint-locking techniques has the effect of stretching, and it prevents stiff shoulder.

sen.j: 試合がないため過剰な稽古をする必要が無く、年齢体力に応じて自然に足腰の鍛練ができる。
sen.e: Since there are no matches, there is no need for excessive training, and discipling of legs and loins can be done naturally depending on age and strength.
Because matches aren't held, there is no need for excessive training, and the discipline of the legs and loins can be done naturally depending on one's age and strength.

sen.j: 盛平自身、折りあるごとに、「合気道は適度な運動で血行を改善し、骨格を矯正し、体内の“気”の流れを整えることで身体の“穢れ”をはらう“禊ぎ”である」…等と独自の宗教的表現で、合気道の健康効果について述べている。
sen.e: Morihei himself spoke of the health benefits of aikido using unique religious expressions, saying 'aikido is a "misogi" which removes the "impurities" of the body by improving blood circulation, correcting bone structure, and adjusting the flow of "qi" in the body through moderate exercise."

Morihei himself spoke of the health benefits of aikido using unique religious expressions, saying that 'aikido is a "misogi" that removes the "impurities" from the body by improving the blood circulation, correcting the bone structure and adjusting the flow of "qi" in the body through moderate exercise.

sen.j: 宗教的な儀式性と健康法を結びつけ、それを稽古の目的の一つとしていることも、他の武道には余り見られないユニークな点である。
sen.e: Another unique point rarely seen in other martial arts is that it links religious ceremonial nature with physical fitness, and positions it as one of the purposes of the training.

sen.j: 「護身術」としての有効性に関する議論
sen.e: Debate on its effectiveness as an 'art of self-defense'
Debate regarding its effectiveness as an 'art of self-defense'
Debate regarding its effectiveness as an 'art of self-defense'

sen.j: 通常の筋力や腕力に頼らず相手を制する武道であるということから、「非力な女性の護身術としても有効」と喧伝されてきており、そのように認識している人も少なくないが、現在その点に関し疑問を呈する声もある。
sen.e: Since it is a martial art which controls the opponent without depending on ordinary muscular strength or force, it has been advertised as 'also effective as an art of self-defense for powerless women,' and many consider it as such, but some are questioning this today.

Because it's a martial art that controls the opponent without depending on ordinary muscular strength or force, aikido has been advertised as being 'effective as an art of self-defense for powerless women,' and though many consider it as such, some are questioning this today.

sen.j: 否定的な意見の根拠としては、次の例などがあり、合気道をそのまま一般的な護身術として考えることに疑義を呈する。
sen.e: Reasons for the negative opinions include the following, questioning the idea of considering aikido as a common art of self-defense.
sen.cmt: 箇条書きの後の「などがあり、合気道をそのまま一般的な護身術として考えることに疑義を呈する。」とまとめて訳しました。

sen.j: 日常の稽古形式が形稽古に終始している道場が大多数である。
sen.e: Form of daily training in majority of the dojo is focused entirely on kata training.
The form of daily training in the majority of the dojo is focused entirely on kata training.
The form of daily training in the majority of the dojo is focused entirely on kata training.

sen.j: 型稽古とは、技をかける方（取り）、かけられる方（受け）を予め決めておき、互いにある程度わかった動きを行う稽古法である。
sen.e: Kata training is a method of training where the attacker (tori) and defender (uke) are predetermined, and movements somewhat known to both parties are performed.
Kata training is a method in which the attacker (tori) and defender (uke) are predetermined, and movements somewhat known to both parties are performed.
Kata training is a method in which the attacker (tori) and defender (uke) are predetermined, and movements somewhat known to both parties are performed.

sen.j: この稽古のときは、受けは本気でこらえることはせず、むしろかけられやすいように動く。
sen.e: In this training, the uke does not seriously respond, but rather move in a way that he/she is more easily attacked.
In this training, the uke doesn't seriously respond but instead moves in such a way that he/she is more easily attacked.
In this training, the uke doesn't seriously respond but instead moves in such a way that he/she is more easily attacked.

sen.j: 返し技（受けが最初に攻撃し、取りがそれを捌きかける技）の練習のときは、受けの最初の攻撃は前もって決まっている。
sen.e: When practicing kaeshi waza (technique in which the uke attacks first, and the tori handles it and attacks), the first attack by the uke is predetermined.
When practicing kaeshi waza (a technique in which the uke attacks first, and the tori handles it and attacks), the first attack by the uke is predetermined.
When practicing kaeshi waza (a technique in which the uke attacks first, and the tori handles it and attacks), the first attack by the uke is predetermined.

sen.j: そのように、相手が抵抗しない、相手の攻撃は前もってわかっている稽古だけで、実際の自由な攻防（相手は抵抗する、相手の攻撃はわからない）への対応力が養えているか疑問。
sen.e: It is questionable whether the skill to respond to actual free offense and defense (the opponent resists, and the opponent's attack is unknown) is built solely through training where the opponent does not resist, and the attack of the opponent is known in advance.

It is questionable whether the skill to respond to actual free offense and defense (the opponent resists, and the opponent's attack is unknown) is built solely through training in which the opponent doesn't resist and the opponent's attack is known in advance.

It is questionable whether the skill to respond to actual free offense and defense (the opponent resists, and the opponent's attack is unknown) is built solely through training in which the opponent doesn't resist and the opponent's attack is known in advance.

sen.j: また、これに関係して、合気道が力を必要としないのは、「稽古では相手が抵抗しない型稽古しか行わないから、普段の稽古では力を必要としない、力で劣る人もできる」という意味であり、「護身術･武術として考えたときに合気道のテクニックが優れており、力を使わずとも相手を投げる･固める･制することが出来る」という意味ではない、という意見もある。
sen.e: Additionally, with regard to this, some say that aikido does not require force because 'in training, only kata training where the opponent does not resist is performed, so daily training does not require force, and people are less strong can perform as well,' and not because 'aikido's techniques are superior as art of self-defense or martial art, and allow throwing, grappling, and controlling of the opponent without force.'

Additionally, with regard to this some say that aikido doesn't require force because 'in training, only kata training where the opponent doesn't resist is performed, so daily training doesn't require force and people who aren't strong can perform as well,' but not because 'aikido's techniques are superior as an art of self-defense or a martial art, allowing one to throw, grapple and control the opponent without force.'

Additionally, with regard to this some say that aikido doesn't require force because 'in training, only kata training where the opponent doesn't resist is performed, so daily training doesn't require force and people who aren't strong can perform as well,' but not because 'aikido's techniques are superior as an art of self-defense or a martial art, allowing one to throw, grapple and control the opponent without force.'

sen.j: またその形稽古の技法が「片手取り」（攻撃者が相手の手首を掴みに来る）「正面打ち」（攻撃者が手刀を振りかぶって打って来る）など、現代の現実の格闘場面では考え難い攻撃法に対処する形になっている（これは合気道の元になった古流柔術が帯刀を前提とした時代のものであり、「抜刀しようと刀の柄に掛けた手を押さえる→片手取り」「刀で斬り掛かって来る→正面打ち」などの場面を想定した稽古法であったことに由来すると言われている）
sen.e: Furthermore, the techniques of kata training such as 'katatedori (the attacker grabs the opponent's wrist), 'shomen-uchi strike' (the attacker swings down a tegatana to hit) are forms for responding to attacks unlikely in today's actual fights (this is due to the fact that old-style jujutsu which was the origin of aikido was from the age when sword on a belt was used, and these training simulated scenes like 'holding down the hand which was placed on the grip of the sword to draw it -> katatedori' and 'being swung down a sword -> shomen-uchi strike')

Furthermore, the techniques of kata training such as 'katatedori (the attacker grabs the opponent's wrist), 'shomen-uchi strike' (the attacker swings down a tegatana to hit) are forms of response to attacks that are unlikely in today's actual fights (this is due to the fact that old-style jujutsu, which was the origin of aikido, was from the age when a sword on a belt was used, and such training simulates scenes such as 'holding down the hand that was placed on the grip of the sword to draw it, i.e., katatedori' and 'being swung down a sword, i.e., shomen-uchi strike).'

Furthermore, the techniques of kata training such as 'katatedori (the attacker grabs the opponent's wrist), 'shomen-uchi strike' (the attacker swings down a tegatana to hit) are forms of response to attacks that are unlikely in today's actual fights (this is due to the fact that old-style jujutsu, which was the origin of aikido, was from the age when a sword on a belt was used, and such training simulates scenes such as 'holding down the hand that was placed on the grip of the sword to draw it, i.e., katatedori' and 'being swung down a sword, i.e., shomen-uchi strike).'

sen.j: 加えて、合気道の型稽古の技法では、「受けは、多少不利な体勢になってもつかんだ手を離さない」や「受けは背中側をとられたら前足を軸に振り向いて相手についていく」や「多少崩れたら、普通に耐えられそうでも受身を取る、（投げられる）」というように、現代の現実の格闘場面では考え難い前提が存在している。
sen.e: In addition, in aikido kata training techniques, there are assumptions such as 'the defender does not let go of the grip even if he/she is in a somewhat disadvantaged position,' 'when the defender is attacked on his back side, he/she turns around on the front foot and follows the opponent,' or 'when balance is lost slightly, perform ukemi even if it feels like it is tolerable (be thrown),' which are unthinkable in today's actual fights.

Additionally, in aikido's kata training techniques there are assumptions such as 'the defender doesn't let go of the grip even if he/she is in a somewhat disadvantaged position,' 'when the defender is attacked on his back side, he/she turns around on the front foot and follows the opponent,' or 'when balance is lost slightly, perform ukemi even if it feels as if it's tolerable (be thrown),' which are unthinkable in today's actual fights.

Additionally, in aikido's kata training techniques there are assumptions such as 'the defender doesn't let go of the grip even if he/she is in a somewhat disadvantaged position,' 'when the defender is attacked on his back side, he/she turns around on the front foot and follows the opponent,' or 'when balance is lost slightly, perform ukemi even if it feels as if it's tolerable (be thrown),' which are unthinkable in today's actual fights.

sen.j: （これも、「手を離さない→刀を押さえているから離すと絶対不利」「前足を軸に振り向いてついていく→刀を持っていると前体重だから軸は前足、刀相手に中途半端な距離をとると絶対不利」「崩れたら受身→刀相手に体勢を立て直そうともたつくよりは、受身で大きく間合いを取るほうがいい」というような理由がある、といわれている。）
sen.e: (These also are believed to have the following reasons behind them, 'do not let go of the grip -> it is absolutely disadvantageous to let go since he/she is holding down a sword,' 'turn around on the front foot and follow -> the front foot is the stem, because the gravity is towards the front when holding a sword, and it is absolutely disadvantageous to be in a halfway distance with an opponent with a sword,' 'ukemi when losing balance -> it is better to take a big distance using ukemi than to struggle to recover one's position when the opponent has a sword.')

(These also are believed to have the following reasons behind them: 'do not let go of the grip -> it is absolutely disadvantageous to let go, since he/she is holding down a sword,' 'turn around on the front foot and follow, i.e., the front foot is the stem, because the center of gravity is toward the front when holding a sword and it's absolutely disadvantageous to be at a halfway distance with an opponent bearing a sword,' 'ukemi when losing balance, i.e., it's better to gain a big distance using ukemi than to struggle to recover one's position when the opponent has a sword.')

(These also are believed to have the following reasons behind them: 'do not let go of the grip -> it is absolutely disadvantageous to let go, since he/she is holding down a sword,' 'turn around on the front foot and follow, i.e., the front foot is the stem, because the center of gravity is toward the front when holding a sword and it's absolutely disadvantageous to be at a halfway distance with an opponent bearing a sword,' 'ukemi when losing balance, i.e., it's better to gain a big distance using ukemi than to struggle to recover one's position when the opponent has a sword.')

sen.j: 実際に筋力・腕力に頼らず相手を制する技術は、とても高度で難しいものであるとが予想できるが、高度で難しい技術の習得には多くの時間を要することが通常であり、社会が護身術に期待する速習速成という要求に応えられない。
sen.e: It can be imagined that techniques to actually control the opponent without depending on muscular strength or force can be very advanced and difficult, but it is normal for advanced and difficult techniques to take a lot of time to learn, and the society's demand for quick training in a crash course for the art of self-defense cannot be met.

sen.j: 一方、日本合気道協会（富木流）では主に対短刀を想定した乱取りを行っており、刃物に対する護身術として理解されている。
sen.e: Meanwhile, Japan Aikido Association (Tomiki ryu) practices randori (throwing practice with both partners trying to throw each other) with short swords in mind, and is considered the art of self-defense against blades.

sen.j: 乱取り稽古を行わない会派では、養神館合気道や岩間神信合氣修練会が積極的に護身術としての合気道を指導している。
sen.e: Among factions that do not practice randori, Yoshinkan aikido and Iwama-shinshin-aikishurenkai (Iwama ryu) actively teach aikido as art of self-defense.

sen.e: There are multiple other aikido practitioners and independent factions that independently study the possibilities of aikido as art of self-defense, and since there are techniques and movements in mixed martial arts and karate that are common with aikido, some see it useful as an art of self-defense.

sen.j: 昭和17年（1942年）、戦時下において武道界を統制する政府の外郭団体・大日本武徳会に設置された「合気道部」と、“総合武術”（体術・剣術などを総合的に扱う武術）として制定された「大日本武徳会合気道」がこの名称の初出とされる。
sen.e: It is believed that this name first appeared in 1942, in 'Aikido-bu' (aikido division) established in the government extra-departmental organization, Dai Nippon Butoku-kai, and 'Dai Nippon Butoku-kai aikido' established as a "comprehensive martial arts" (martial arts integrating taijutsu, swordplay, etc).

sen.j: 当時盛平は大日本武徳会から総合武術部門設立についての協力要請を受けたが、これに対し皇武館道場の「総務」であった平井稔を推薦した。
sen.e: Morihei, at that time was requested from Dai Nippon Butoku-kai to cooperate in the establishment of a comprehensive martial arts department, and in response, he referred Minoru HIRAI, who was a 'General Director' at Kobukan dojo.
